First constraints on the running of nonGaussianity
Adam Becker
Dragan Huterer
Department of Physics, University of Michigan, 450 Church St, Ann Arbor, MI 48109 1040
$\ast$
Emailbeckeramumich. edu
$\ast\ast$
Emailhutererumich. edu
Abstract
We use data from the WMAP temperature maps to constrain a scaledependent
generalization of the popularlocalmodel for primordial nonGaussianity.
In the model where the parameter
$f_\mathrm{NL}$
is allowed to run with scale
$k$
,
$f_\mathrm{NL}(k)=f_\mathrm{NL}^*(k/k_\mathrm{piv})^{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
,
we constrain the running to be
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}=0.30^{+1.9}_{-1.2}$
at 95 confidence, marginalized over the amplitude
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
.
The constraints depend somewhat on the prior probabilities
assigned to the two parameters. In the near future, constraints from a
combination of Planck and largescale structure surveys are expected to
improve this limit by about an order of magnitude and usefully constrain
classes of inflationary models.
2

body.section:
Introduction
NonGaussianity in the distribution of primordial density
fluctuations provides a unique window into the physics of
inflation. The magnitude of primordial nonGaussianity and its dependence on
scale provide information about the dynamics of scalar field(s), their
interactions, and the speed of sound during inflation. Constraints on
nonGaussianity have traditionally come from the measurements of the
threepoint correlation function of the cosmic microwave background(CMB)
temperature anisotropies. Upper limits from COBE 1
have been
improved by two orders of magnitude by the WMAP experiment
2
.
Moreover, clustering of galaxies and galaxy clusters has also
been identified as a powerful probe of nonGaussianity 3
, already
leading to interesting constraints that are complementary in their information
content to the CMB measurements.
So far most attention has been devoted to thelocalmodel of primordial
nonGaussianity, where the primordial Newtonian potential
$\phi(x)$
is
modified with a quadratic term
$\phi=\phi_G+f_\mathrm{NL}(\phi_G^2-\langle\phi_G^2\rangle)$
, where
$\phi_G$
is a Gaussian potential
4
.
The parameter
$f_\mathrm{NL}$
is currently constrained to be
$32\pm21$
by WMAP( 2
see also
5,6
)
and
$28\pm23$
by the
largescale structure 7-9
. Several
other nonGaussian models have been constrained as well
(
e. g. 10,11
). However, therunningwith physical
scale of these models, which may carry important information about the
number of inflationary fields and their interactions
-1,12-20
2012 tk, Kobayashi_Takahashi, has not yet been constrained
with current data(except for a very rough estimate of the angularmultipole
dependence of
$f_\mathrm{NL}$
11
and implicit constraints on a
braneworldmotivated model 23
). Such constraints have only been
forecasted for future experiments
24-28
.
Constraining the running of nonGaussianity therefore presents a major new
opportunity to probe inflationary physics, and is just becoming feasible. In
this Letter, we present the first such constraints.

section.title: Methods
Model
section.p: In this work we consider a physically motivated generalization

of the local model, where the parameter
$f_\mathrm{NL}$
is promoted to a function of

scale
$k$
. In particular, we seek to constrain the twoparameter powerlaw
subclass of the generalized models 25

where
$k_*$
is an arbitrary fixed parameter, leaving
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
and
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
as
the parameters of interest in this model. Such scaling is expected in
inflation when more than one field dominates or when there is
selfinteraction, and its signatures in the CMB and LSS have been discussed in

the literature 24,25,29
. The parameter
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
is

often, though certainly not always, expected to be
$\lesssimO(1)$
in
inflationary models, but in our phenomenological model it is allowed to take
any value.

section.section:
Bispectrum and
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
estimator
The primordial bispectrum of the
$f_\mathrm{NL}(k)$
model from Eq. eqfnlk
is
straightforward to calculate
\begin{equation}F(\vec{k}_1,\vec{k}_2,\vec{k}_3)=2\left[f_\mathrm{NL}(k_1)P(k_2)P(k_3)+\mathrm{perm.}\right],\end{equation}
where the full bispectrum is
$B(\vec{k}_1,\vec{k}_2,\vec{k}_3)\equiv(2\pi)^3\delta(\vec{k}_1+\vec{k}_2+\vec{k}_3)F(\vec{k}_1,\vec{k}_2,\vec{k}_3)$
. Here
$P$
is the power spectrum of the primordial curvature perturbations, and
$\delta$
is the Dirac delta function.
Constraining the running parameter
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
seems difficult because of the
apparent requirement to find an estimator for a parameter in an exponent. To
avoid this, we resort to an indirect approach where, for a fixed
value
of
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
, we estimate the parameter
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
using modifications of the
wellknown KSW estimator 30
, which is
known to be nearly optimal
31,32
.
We then iterate over the
values of the running
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
to obtain the full likelihood
$\mathcal{L}(f_\mathrm{NL}^*,{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})$
.
The theoretical expectation for the bispectrum of the temperature anisotropies
in the cosmic microwave background can be explicitly evaluated, starting from
the definition of the generalized nonGaussian local model in Eq. eqfnlk
to account for the running
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
where
$I_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}$
is the Gaunt integral and
Here,
$t_\ell$
is the radiation transfer function, which can be calculated
using CAMB 33
.
Following
KSW 30
we can
define new, filtered maps
$A(\mathbf{\hat{n}},r)$
and
$B(\mathbf{\hat{n}},r)$
,
Then, we write down the skewness
$S({n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})$
\begin{equation}S({n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})\equiv\intr^2dr\intd^2\mathbf{\hat{n}}\,A(\mathbf{\hat{n}},r)B^2(\mathbf{\hat{n}},r),\label{eq:skew}\end{equation}
which requires
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
as input(through
$A$
), and does not require a priori
knowledge of
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
.
The observed CMB bispectrum is defined as
$B_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}^{\mathrm{obs.}}=\langlea_{\ell_1m_1}a_{\ell_2m_2}a_{\ell_3m_3}\rangle$
, and
$S({n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})$
therefore
reduces to
\begin{equation}S=\sum_{\ell_1\leq\ell_2\leq\ell_3}{B^{\mathrm{obs}}_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}\tilde{B}^{\mathrm{theory}}_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}(f_\mathrm{NL}=1)\over\tilde{C}_{\ell_1}\tilde{C}_{\ell_2}\tilde{C}_{\ell_3}},\label{SkewBispec}\end{equation}
where
$\tilde{B}^{\mathrm{theory}}_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}=b_{\ell_1}b_{\ell_2}b_{\ell_3}B^{\mathrm{theory}}_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}$
, and
$b_\ell$
is the beam transfer function.
We now define
$F\equivF({n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})$
, the Fisher matrix for
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
, equivalent to the cumulative
signaltonoise squared of the theoretical bispectrum for
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*=1$
\begin{equation}F({n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})=\sum_{\ell_1\leq\ell_2\leq\ell_3}{\left(\tilde{B}^{\mathrm{theory}}_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}(f_\mathrm{NL}^*=1)\right)^2\over\tilde{C}_{\ell_1}\tilde{C}_{\ell_2}\tilde{C}_{\ell_3}}.\label{eq:Fisher}\end{equation}
The theoretical expectation for
$B_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}\proptof_\mathrm{NL}^*$
, so the cubic KSW
estimator for
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
is
\begin{equation}\hat{f}_\mathrm{NL}^*={S\overF}.\label{eq:KSW}\end{equation}
We used HEALPix, by way of HealPy, to do the forwards and backwards spherical
harmonic transforms required to obtain the
$A$
and
$B$
maps.

section.title: Cutsky maps
section.p: Equationeqref eqKSWworks well for a fullsky map,
but a sky cut introduces a spurious nonGaussian signal. To account for the

masking of the CMB sky, we make the substitution
$S\rightarrowS_{\mathrm{cut}}=S/f_\mathrm{sky}+S_{\mathrm{linear}}$
34
.
$S_{\mathrm{linear}}$
is an addition to

skewness from Eq. eqskew
, calibrated to account for partialsky
observations

The subscripted filtered maps
$A_{\mathrm{sim}}$
and
$B_{\mathrm{sim}}$
are created

from PythonproducedMonte Carlo realizations of the cut CMB skythe brackets
$\langle\rangle_{MC}$
indicate an average over all 300 MontePython maps. The simulated
maps were produced using the prescription laid out in Appendix A of the WMAP5

paper 35
the only difference(aside from using the WMAP7
cosmological model)is that we used a uniform weighting for the maps,
rather than the slightly more complicated weighting given there, since it only

gives a marginal improvement in estimating
$f_\mathrm{NL}$
.

section.section:
Likelihood Evaluation
To find the likelihood, we first find a
$\chi^2$
statistic for
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
, given a value of
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
. Taking the angularaveraged
bispectrum
$B_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}$
as our observables, we have
(
Again, this works because the theoretical expectation for
$B_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}\proptof_\mathrm{NL}^*$
. )Using Eqs. eqref SkewBispecandeqref eqFisher, we can
rewrite
$\chi^2$
as
\begin{equation}\chi^2(f_\mathrm{NL}^*,{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})=F\left(f_\mathrm{NL}^*-{S\overF}\right)^2+\chi^2_0-{S^2\overF}.\label{eq:chi2}\end{equation}
where
$\chi^2_0\equiv\sum_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}\left(B^{\mathrm{obs}}_{\ell_1\ell_2\ell_3}\right)^2/(\tilde{C}_{\ell_1}\tilde{C}_{\ell_2}\tilde{C}_{\ell_3})$
is the
goodnessoffit parameter for the data with respect to the
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*=0$
case. Note that the numerator of
$\chi^2_0$
is an observed quantity, and the
denominator is based solely on the theoretical prediction for the power
spectrum(as well as a few noise and beam parameters of WMAP). Therefore,
$\chi^2_0$
does not depend on
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
or
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
at all. We can use
the definition of
$\hat{f}_\mathrm{NL}^*$
in Eq. eqref eqKSWto rewrite the
expression for
$\chi^2$
as follows
\begin{equation}\chi^2(f_\mathrm{NL}^*,{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})=F\left(f_\mathrm{NL}^*-\hat{f}^*_{\mathrm{NL}}\right)^2+\chi^2_0-(\hat{f}_\mathrm{NL}^*)^2F.\end{equation}
For a fixed value of
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
, the
$\chi^2$
is, as expected, minimized in
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
when
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*=\hat{f}_\mathrm{NL}^*$
, and one obtains
$\chi_{\mathrm{min}}^2({n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})=\chi^2_0-(\hat{f}_\mathrm{NL}^*)^2F$
.
A more interesting task is to calculate the
constraints when
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
is allowed to vary.
With an expression for
$\chi^2(f_\mathrm{NL}^*,{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})$
in hand, we can write an expression for the
likelihood,
$\mathcal{L}(f_\mathrm{NL}^*,{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})\propto\exp(-{\chi^2/2})$
(dropping
the constant term with
$\chi_0^2$
)
To marginalize over
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
is also straightforward
\begin{equation}\mathcal{L}({n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})=\int\mathcal{L}({n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}},f_\mathrm{NL}^*)\:df_\mathrm{NL}^*\propto{1\over\sqrt{F}}\exp\left[{(\hat{f}_\mathrm{NL}^*)^2F\over2}\right],\end{equation}
where, recall,
$F({n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}})$
is defined in Eq. eqFisher
.

section.title: Results
section.section:
WMAP7 constraints on
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
Figure figlikelihood
shows the
likelihood
$\mathcal{L}$
in the
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
plane, as well as the
likelihood for
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
alone, calculated from the WMAP7 temperature maps. We
used a weighted and masked combination of the WMAP V and W band maps
with the monopole and dipole subtracted, as recommended by the WMAP
team 35
. To extract full information from WMAP maps, we used
multipoles out to
$\ell_{\mathrm{max}}=800$
for the sums in Eqs. eqA_map
,
eqB_map
and eqFisher
. We did not find a significant
improvement between
$\ell_{\mathrm{max}}=700$
and
$\ell_{\mathrm{max}}=800$
we chose the higher
value to be conservative in our analysis.
The quantity
$\chi^2$
is independent of our choice for
$k_{\mathrm{piv}}$
,
but the likelihood itself is not, since
$F$
is inversely proportional to
$k_{\mathrm{piv}}^{2{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}}$
.
The true pivot scale favored by the data is the value
of
$k_{\mathrm{piv}}$
for which the errors in
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
are uncorrelated with the
errors in
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
. We find this scale by using the likelihood to calculate the
covariance matrix
$\mathbf{C}$
between
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
and
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
\begin{equation}\mathbf{C}_{p_i,p_j}=\langle(p_i-\bar{p_i})(p_j-\bar{p_j})\rangle.\end{equation}
We can easily find the pivot value
$k_{\mathrm{piv}}$
that diagonalizes the
covariance matrix
$\mathbf{C}$
(see e. g. Ref. 26
)
\begin{equation}k_\mathrm{piv}=k_*\exp\left(-{\mathbf{C}_{f_\mathrm{NL}^*,{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}}\overf_\mathrm{NL}^*\mathbf{C}_{{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}},{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}}}\right).\label{eq:kpiv}\end{equation}
where
$k_*$
is the(arbitrary)pivot used initially, and
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
is the
corresponding value used in
$\mathbf{C}$
. Despite the fact that
$k_*$
and
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
show up in the expression,
$k_\mathrm{piv}$
does not depend on themit is a
fixed number telling us roughly where the experiment has greatest power(and
where normalization and running of
$f_\mathrm{NL}(k)$
are precisely uncorrelated). We
find that
$k_\mathrm{piv}^{\mathrm{WMAP7}}\approx0.064\,h\,\mathrm{Mpc}^{-1}$
. The 68 , 95 , and
99 constraints on
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
and
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
are shown at the left panel of Figure
figlikelihood
, assuming flat priors on
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
and
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
and
$k_*=k_\mathrm{piv}^{\mathrm{WMAP7}}\approx0.064\,h\,\mathrm{Mpc}^{-1}$
.

Dependence on the prior
As with most presentday cosmological
measurements, the precise constraints depend on the prior probability on the
parameters we are constraining. Even for a simple flat prior on
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
and
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
,
the actual effective prior depends on the a priori
chosen pivot
in wavenumber
$k_*$
. For example, a flat prior on
$(f_\mathrm{NL}^*)^{(1)}\equivf_\mathrm{NL}(k_{*,1})$
defined at some pivot
$k_{*,1}$
corresponds to a nonflat prior on some
$(f_\mathrm{NL}^*)^{(2)}\equivf_\mathrm{NL}^*(k_{*,2})$
defined at some other pivot
$k_{*,2}$
, since
$(f_\mathrm{NL}^*)^{(2)}\equiv(f_\mathrm{NL}^*)^{(1)}(k_{*,2}/k_{*,1})^{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
.
If we
assume some alternate pivot
$k_{*,2}$
but hold the flat prior in
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
,
the contours in the
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
plane(left panel of
Fig. figlikelihood
are stretched vertically by a factor of
$(k_{*,2}/0.064\:h\,\mathrm{Mpc}^{-1})^{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
.
We have experimented with different kpivot values for a flat prior on
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
and
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
. We have also investigated other possibilities, such as
the prior that assigns equal weight to each decade in
$|f_\mathrm{NL}^*|$
above 0.1
(
so uniform in
$\log(f_\mathrm{NL}^*)$
, but cut off at the arguably lowestever
observable value of
$|f_\mathrm{NL}^*|=0.1$
so that the total integrated likelihood is
finite). We present the two aforementioned examples, showing constraints on
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
marginalized over
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
, in the right panel of
Fig. figlikelihood
. In the end, we decide to quote results for the flat
prior and the uncorrelated
$k_\mathrm{piv}$
value from Eq. eqkpiv
, which most
closely follows priors to both nonGaussian and other cosmological parameters
applied in the literature.
Putting it all together, we can get the estimate for
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
from the
WMAP7 data for a flat prior on
$f_\mathrm{NL}^*$
at the pivot
$k_\mathrm{piv}$
from
Eq. eqkpiv
. The
$68\%$
$(95\%)$
confidence interval is
\begin{equation}{n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}=0.30^{+0.78\,(1.9)}_{-0.61\,(1.2)}\,.\label{eq:nfnl_result}\end{equation}
The current constraints are therefore fully consistent with no running,
as Fig. figlikelihood
clearly indicates.
Figure
figerrorprop_WMAP7
shows the constraints in the
$f_\mathrm{NL}(k)$
plane together with a
few representative models allowed by the data.

body.section:
Discussion
We have presented the first constraints on the
scaledependence of(any form of)nonGaussianity using the WMAP7 data. The
constraints are compatible with zero running,
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}=0$
, with very mild(
$<1$
sigma)
preference for a positive value of
${n_{f_\mathrm{NL}}}$
. We will learn more soon
the Planck data and the data from upcoming largescale structure surveys
should be able to improve constraints on the running of nonGaussianity by about an order
of magnitude 24,27,28
, thus
shedding important new light on the physics of inflation.
